Could not get decent looking streams to appear without burning them in first
0.67 SM average area, a bit too small with the target min being 1.1, some long and skinny DA's
DA's not touching the streams encompass 3-5 of the previously delineated DA's. However, there are tons of long skinny slivers along the streams. This delineation would not be acceptable as is.
Isobasins- target size 28490 cells = 1.1 SM (1 click delineation)

This looks like a vectorization of a flow direction grid or something. It took so long to vectorize just because it's countless tiny slivers. This tool is definitely doing something incorrectly with the default params.

Did a pretty good job. This was a fairly automated delineation, with no stream burning or extracting. The boundaries match up exactly with the WBT_rasterized_NHD_named_streams subbasins, except it did much better about not including a bunch of microscopic DA's. There are still a few as small as 0.03 SM along the rivers, however, even though the min cells per basin was specified to make this 1.1 SM. This solution would still require some cleaning up at the end.

Could not find a method to delineate more than 1 subbasin from extracted streams. There is a tool called r.basins.fill which presumably should do this, however, its documentation is limited and I wasn't able to get it to produce results that made sense. There is an input 'thinned ridge network raster layer' which the docs simply describe as 'need to be created by hand'.
r.watershed This time using 1050000 for min # cells, 10GB for max memory rather than default 300MB

Since I was seeing basins as small as ~0.03 SM, I multiplied the min cells by 1.1/0.03. The result was a dozen enormous basins. I also let up from the default memory limit from 300MB to 10GB and performance increased accordingly. I also switched from the default MFD to D8
r.watershed using D8 pointer and original estimate 1.1 SM min basin size, 13GB for max memory

This was the best so far, average DA size is 1.5 SM. It looks identical to the first GRASS r.watershed trial, but removed many of the smallest DA's. There are still somehow subbasins as small as ~0.07SM, so that min grid cells number would need to be massaged further from here.
Fill sinks (wang & liu)- the result loses its UTM projection. Needed to reproject
Channel Network and Drainage Basins; threshold 5

This tool is nice in that like TauDEM from HMS, it also gives you Junctions and Reaches and their connectivity. So far this would be the only serious contender for a delineation meant to be used in HMS as those pieces could simply be imported. The subbasins, however, are really wonky. They only cover isolated patches of the watershed, and don't really follow any rules. There are some subbasins which are completely bounded by a larger subbasin.
Strahler order operation misses the rivers entirely if they are not first burned in
Rasterize NHD vector, Burn Stream Network into DEM: trace downstream; epsilon 1000
Trace downstream option still misses the rivers
Rasterize NHD vector, Burn Stream Network into DEM: lower cell - epsilon (1000)
Channel Network and Drainage Basins; threshold 5

This is even worse, same delineation as the first without burned streams except it covers a bit less area. There are no subbasins within ~500m from the NHD rivers, which still aren't being picked up well after being burned in.
Rasterize NHD vector, Burn Stream Network into DEM: lower cell - epsilon (1000)
Channel Network and Drainage Basins; threshold 3

This one is identical to the previous, except it covers the whole watershed area. What was missing gaps before SAGA apparently identified as lower strahler order (along the actual rivers which should be higher order). It seems to get a good delineation for this region one would have to burn in the whole stream network rather than just major rivers, and then merge the small basins manually.
Lddcreate; Default options. Fills sinks and creates flow dir map

Streamorder. Raster Calculator: ("Stream Order layer@1" >=8)*"Stream Order layer@1". Convert to PCRaster Format (LDD). Downstream (of strahler). Raster calc ("strahler@1" = "Downstream layer@1" -1 ). Convert to PCRaster Format (boolean) -> this is your junctions. uniqueid. convert datatype (nominal). spatial (0, mask: junctions lyr, nominal) to create a nominal layer of all 0's. cover (junctions, fill data check on nominal 0's, not sure why this is necessary). These processes are better explained in this video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5uGaLIlaFh8

Another discretization by Strahler order rather than subbasin area paradigm here. I was pretty impressed with the resulting subbasins. It found the stream and river network perfectly without having to burn in the NHD.
Lddcreate; Default options. Fills sinks and creates flow dir map

Same steps tested through the python API, the resulting subbasins were the same. Inspecting the junctions calculated by strahler order, I would add a couple more in some locations manually if I was really dialing in this delineation. This was a much friendlier experience from a user standpoint, they even have a fantastic built-in raster calculator that alleviates all the extra QGIS steps, as well as a linked GIS visualization utility called Aguila.
